nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"ok -> i will explain you the current state of the project: 1. demuxing and decoding videoframes while recording causes recording to glitch 2. i don't like how we handled auto-resolver -> we need to reconsider how we compile a possibly complexly nested graph of tracks and groups and clips into an easy queryable datastructure so we don't have to calculate anything during scrubbing 3. when demuxing and decoding more then 3 videos jank starts to appear 4. there is the idea of doing pre-rendering and compositing this with the preview, but that would prevent us from rendering atop of the grid (currently not implemented: everything is in a grid for the MVP, but for future consideration) 4. we had implemented preview rendering at some point, but i decided to remove it during a previous simplification of the library. 5. for the mvp we also want to be able to record over the same track in a later offset -> and loop 6. but before we implement we have to focus first on the performance aspect -> if we can not play it smoothly and record at the same time the project is doomed -> formalize this in a series of issues and let's add them to remote"}

nodes.title: Created 5 GitHub issues with prioritization
How to handle demuxing/decoding performance for smooth playback + recording
Option A: Pause decode during recording
Option B: Pre-decode all frames to memory before playback
Option C: Lower decode priority/quality during recording
Option D: Use different codec/format more suited for editing (ProRes-like)
Option E: Offload decode to GPU via WebGPU/WebGL
How to measure/profile performance bottlenecks
Option A: Chrome DevTools Performance tab + screenshot
Option B: User Timing API (performance.mark/measure) + export
Option C: stats.js (FPS/MS/MB overlay)
Option D: PerformanceObserver + structured JSON export
Option E: Playwright + CDP tracing (automated, headless)
Scaffold Playwright performance testing workflow
Existing perf infrastructure found: scripts/perf-test.ts + @eddy/utils/perf
Committed: fix SolidJS store mutation bug and type errors
Committed: add perf instrumentation to playback workers
Baseline perf: 4-track VP9 decode ~6ms/frame/track, bufferAhead spikes to 76ms on keyframes
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Performance test results (4-track VP9 playback, 10s duration):

MAIN THREAD:
- renderLoop: 0.05ms avg, 0.18ms max, 0% slow frames
- Effective FPS: ~18595 (loop overhead only, work offloaded to workers)

PER-TRACK WORKER STATS (all 4 tracks similar):
- bufferAhead: ~7ms avg, 76ms max, ~2.5% slow
- decode: ~6ms avg, 28ms max, ~1% slow
- transferFrame: ~0.25ms avg, ~2ms max, 0% slow
- demux: ~0.05ms avg, <1ms max, 0% slow

KEY FINDINGS:
1. Decode is the bottleneck (~6ms per frame per track)
2. 4 tracks * 6ms = 24ms total decode time (exceeds 16.67ms frame budget for 60fps)
3. bufferAhead spikes to 76ms occasionally (keyframe decode)
4. Main thread is very fast - worker architecture is effective
5. No dropped frames in test (buffering ahead compensates)

IMPLICATIONS FOR DECISION #34 (demux/decode performance):
- Current approach works for pure playback
- Recording + playback would add ~10-20ms per frame for muxing
- Options B (pre-decode) or C (lower priority during record) most promising"}

nodes.title: test-with-audio.webm causes VideoFrame construction failure - data size mismatch
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":75,"prompt":"Bug discovered during perf testing:

test-with-audio.webm and test-clip.webm cause errors:
- "Failed to construct 'VideoFrame': data is not large enough"
- Error in dataToFrame() at playback.worker.ts:30
- Clips report as loaded (hasClip=true) but playback fails

test-vp9.webm works correctly.

Possible causes:
1. Audio track interfering with video demuxing
2. Different encoding parameters in test files
3. Frame buffer getting corrupted data

Updated perf-test.ts to default to test-vp9.webm"}

nodes.title: Option F: SharedArrayBuffer priority coordinator - lock-free cross-worker priority signaling
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"SharedArrayBuffer-based priority coordination:

MECHANISM:
- Central SharedArrayBuffer shared across all workers
- Atomic flags: RECORDING_ACTIVE, DECODE_PRIORITY (0=low, 1=normal, 2=high)
- Recording worker sets RECORDING_ACTIVE=1, DECODE_PRIORITY=0
- Playback workers check priority before each decode operation
- When priority=low: skip non-keyframes, reduce buffer-ahead

PROS:
- Lock-free (uses Atomics.load/store)
- Very low overhead (~nanoseconds to check)
- Already using this pattern for audio ring buffer
- True cross-worker synchronization

CONS:
- Requires SharedArrayBuffer (needs COOP/COEP headers)
- Manual priority logic in each worker
- No browser-level scheduling integration

IMPLEMENTATION SKETCH:
```ts
// Priority coordinator (shared)
const RECORDING_ACTIVE = 0
const DECODE_PRIORITY = 1
const coord = new Int32Array(new SharedArrayBuffer(8))

// Recording worker
Atomics.store(coord, RECORDING_ACTIVE, 1)
Atomics.store(coord, DECODE_PRIORITY, 0) // low

// Playback worker - before decode
if (Atomics.load(coord, RECORDING_ACTIVE) && !sample.isKeyframe) {
  return // skip non-keyframe during recording
}
```"}

nodes.title: Option G: Scheduler API (scheduler.postTask) - browser-native priority scheduling
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":75,"prompt":"Browser's Scheduler API for priority-based task scheduling:

MECHANISM:
- Use scheduler.postTask() with priority hints
- Recording: 'user-blocking' (highest priority)
- Playback decode: 'user-visible' normally, 'background' during recording
- Browser scheduler handles thread contention intelligently

PROS:
- Browser-native, well-optimized
- Integrates with browser's rendering pipeline
- No manual coordination needed
- Works across workers

CONS:
- Relatively new API (Chrome 94+, no Firefox/Safari)
- Less granular control than manual approach
- Can't guarantee frame timing
- Polyfill needed for unsupported browsers

IMPLEMENTATION SKETCH:
```ts
// Recording - highest priority
await scheduler.postTask(() => muxFrame(frame), { priority: 'user-blocking' })

// Playback - yield to recording
await scheduler.postTask(() => decodeFrame(sample), { 
  priority: isRecording ? 'background' : 'user-visible' 
})

// Or use scheduler.yield() to let higher priority run
for (const sample of samples) {
  await scheduler.yield()
  decode(sample)
}
```"}

nodes.title: Option H: Backpressure + adaptive quality - workers signal load, coordinator throttles
Option I: Hybrid - SharedArrayBuffer flags + RPC backpressure + adaptive decode
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"Hybrid approach combining multiple mechanisms:

LAYER 1: SharedArrayBuffer (immediate coordination)
- Atomic RECORDING_ACTIVE flag
- Playback workers check before EVERY decode
- Zero-latency priority signal

LAYER 2: RPC backpressure (adaptive tuning)
- Recording worker reports mux time via RPC
- If mux time > threshold: playback reduces aggressively
- Smooth adaptation vs binary on/off

LAYER 3: Adaptive decode strategies
- Skip non-keyframes when recording
- Reduce buffer-ahead (30 → 5 frames)
- Accept stale frames (show last good frame)

PRIORITY GUARANTEE:
Recording: ALWAYS mux every frame (perfect capture)
Playback: Best-effort, graceful degradation

WHY HYBRID:
- SharedArrayBuffer: instant signaling, no async overhead
- RPC: rich metadata, tunable thresholds
- Adaptive: smooth user experience during recording

IMPLEMENTATION:
```ts
// Shared control
const ctrl = new Int32Array(sharedBuffer)
const RECORDING = 0

// Recording starts
Atomics.store(ctrl, RECORDING, 1)
notifyPlaybackWorkers({ mode: 'recording', muxBudget: 10 })

// Playback worker decode loop
if (Atomics.load(ctrl, RECORDING) && !sample.isKeyframe) {
  continue // instant skip
}
await decode(sample)
```"}

nodes.title: scheduler.postTask NOT suitable for frame timing - only for task prioritization
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Clarification on Option G (Scheduler API):

NOT SUITABLE FOR:
- Frame rendering timing (needs vsync alignment)
- Precise timing guarantees (browser decides when)
- Real-time frame delivery

ONLY USEFUL FOR:
- Prioritizing decode work vs mux work
- Hinting "this task more important than that"
- Background work deferral

ACTUAL FRAME RENDERING NEEDS:
- requestAnimationFrame for display timing (vsync-aligned)
- VideoFrame API for compositor delivery
- SharedArrayBuffer for instant cross-worker signaling

CONCLUSION:
Option G is a "nice to have" for background work scheduling, but NOT a solution for the core frame timing problem. Options F (SharedArrayBuffer) and H (backpressure) are the real solutions.

Downgrade Option G from "solution" to "supplementary optimization"."}

nodes.title: Which edit-friendly codec/format to use for fast seeking and decode?
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"Sub-decision under Option D (node 38).

Requirements for edit-friendly codec:
1. All keyframes (intra-frame only) - instant seeking
2. Fast decode - ideally hardware accelerated  
3. WebCodecs support - must work in browser
4. Reasonable file size - mobile-friendly
5. Good quality - no generation loss during editing

This is a critical architectural decision affecting:
- Recording format (what we capture to)
- Storage format (what we save)
- Playback format (what we decode)
- Export format (what we output)

May need different formats for different stages.","issue":1}

nodes.title: VP9 all-keyframe - WebM compatible, good hardware decode support
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"VP9 with all keyframes:

CONFIG:
```ts
encoder.configure({
  codec: 'vp09.00.10.08',
  width, height,
  bitrate: 8_000_000,
  latencyMode: 'realtime',
})
encoder.encode(frame, { keyFrame: true }) // every frame
```

CHARACTERISTICS:
- WebM container: yes
- WebCodecs: full support
- Hardware decode: Chrome, modern devices
- File size: 5-8x larger than normal VP9
- Decode speed: faster than P-frame chain (~2-3ms vs 6ms)
- Encode speed: moderate

UNKNOWNS:
- Actual decode improvement needs testing
- Mobile hardware decode varies"}

nodes.title: VP8 all-keyframe - WebM compatible, widest hardware support
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":80,"prompt":"VP8 with all keyframes:

CONFIG:
```ts
encoder.configure({
  codec: 'vp8',
  width, height,
  bitrate: 10_000_000,
})
encoder.encode(frame, { keyFrame: true })
```

CHARACTERISTICS:
- WebM container: yes
- WebCodecs: full support
- Hardware decode: very wide (older devices too)
- File size: larger than VP9 (less efficient codec)
- Decode speed: fast, simple codec
- Encode speed: fast

TRADE-OFF:
- Better compatibility than VP9
- Worse compression than VP9
- Older codec, less optimized"}

nodes.title: AV1 all-keyframe - WebM compatible, best compression, slow encode
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":70,"prompt":"AV1 with all keyframes:

CONFIG:
```ts
encoder.configure({
  codec: 'av01.0.04M.08',
  width, height,
  bitrate: 6_000_000,
})
encoder.encode(frame, { keyFrame: true })
```

CHARACTERISTICS:
- WebM container: yes
- WebCodecs: partial (encode support varies)
- Hardware decode: newer chips only (2020+)
- File size: smallest (best compression)
- Decode speed: moderate
- Encode speed: SLOW (2-10x slower than VP9)

TRADE-OFF:
- Best compression
- But slow encode problematic for real-time recording
- Hardware decode limited to newer devices
- May not be viable for mobile-first app"}

nodes.title: VP9 all-keyframe benchmark: 10% faster decode, 80% fewer slow frames, 4.7x file size
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Benchmark: VP9 normal vs VP9 all-keyframe (4 tracks, 10s playback)

NORMAL VP9 (test-vp9.webm, 1.7MB):
- decode: 6.0ms avg, 28ms max, 1% slow
- bufferAhead: 7.0ms avg, 76ms max

VP9 ALL-KEYFRAME (test-vp9-allkey.webm, 8.0MB):
- decode: 5.4ms avg, 25ms max, 0.2% slow
- bufferAhead: 8.2ms avg, 72ms max

ANALYSIS:
- Decode ~10% faster (no P-frame dependency chain)
- Max spike reduced (28ms → 25ms)
- Slow frames reduced 80% (1% → 0.2%)
- File size 4.7x larger

CONCLUSION:
All-keyframe provides modest decode improvement but NOT transformative.
The 5.4ms per frame is still significant - 4 tracks = 21.6ms total.
Main benefit is reduced variance (fewer spikes).

File size trade-off may not be worth it for mobile-first app.
Better to focus on priority coordination (Options F/H/I) than codec change."}

nodes.title: VideoFrame stride alignment fix: copyTo() packs data densely but constructor expects 128-byte aligned strides. Fix calculates aligned layout for all YUV/RGB formats.
Layout resolver architecture: track-centric slots vs layout-segment-centric placements
Track-centric slots (current): Slot per track with nested segments per clip. Query O(slots × segments), viewport duplicated.
Layout-segment-centric: Segments are periods of stable layout, each with flat placements list. Query O(log n), supports animated layouts.
Key insight: Layout is about space × time, not tracks. Segments should represent periods of stable layout, with flat placement lists for O(log n) query.
Playback workers should be per-clip not per-track - each clip is independent, frames tagged with clipId
Per-stem workers considered but rejected - multiple clips using same stem at different positions need independent buffers
Worker pool needed to reuse PlaybackWorkers across clips - avoids initialization overhead while keeping clips independent
Refactor to clip-based playback workers with worker pool
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"User exploration led to architecture decision:
1. Layout resolver should use segment-based model with flat placements
2. Playback workers should be per-clip (not per-track)
3. Frames tagged with clipId instead of trackId
4. Worker pool to reuse workers and avoid init overhead

Implementation phases:
- Phase 1: Create WorkerPool for playback workers
- Phase 2: Refactor create-player.ts: TrackEntry → ClipEntry, keyed by clipId
- Phase 3: Update playback.worker.ts: tag frames with clipId
- Phase 4: Update compositor.worker.ts: receive frames by clipId
- Phase 5: New layout types + compiler with segment/placement model"}
